sections.title: Common Questions
content: Q: When should I use degrees vs radians mode? Use degrees when working with angles in everyday contexts (a 90¬∞ right angle, 360¬∞ circle) or geometry problems. Use radians for calculus, advanced math, and physics - most formulas involving trigonometric derivatives (like d/dx[sin(x)] = cos(x)) only work in radians. If you get nonsensical answers (like sin(90) = 0.89 instead of 1), you're probably in the wrong mode. Quick check: sin(90¬∞) = 1, but sin(90 radians) ‚âà 0.89.

Q: How do I calculate complex expressions like (5¬≤ + 3) √ó log(100)? Enter the expression exactly as written using standard mathematical notation. The calculator respects order of operations (PEMDAS): parentheses first, then exponents (5¬≤ = 25), then multiplication/division, then addition/subtraction. For this example: (25 + 3) √ó log(100) = 28 √ó 2 = 56. Use parentheses liberally to ensure the calculator interprets your expression correctly.

Q: What's the difference between log and ln? 'log' means log base 10 (common logarithm): log(100) = 2 because 10¬≤ = 100. 'ln' means natural logarithm (base e): ln(e) = 1 because e¬π = e. In science and engineering, ln is more common because it appears naturally in calculus (d/dx[ln(x)] = 1/x). In everyday contexts (pH, decibels, Richter scale), log base 10 is standard. If a formula says 'log' without specifying base, it usually means log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ in applied fields or ln in pure math - check context.

Q: How do I calculate factorials and what are they used for? Factorial (n!) means multiply all positive integers up to n: 5! = 5√ó4√ó3√ó2√ó1 = 120. Factorials grow extremely fast (10! = 3,628,800). They're used in probability (calculating permutations and combinations), statistics (probability distributions), and calculus (Taylor series). For example, the number of ways to arrange 5 books is 5! = 120 different orders. For combinations, like choosing 3 students from 10, use: 10!/(3!√ó7!) = 120.

Q: Can I use this for physics calculations with scientific notation? Yes! Enter scientific notation using standard formats: 3e8 for 3√ó10‚Å∏ (speed of light: 300,000,000 m/s), 6.02e23 for Avogadro's number, 9.8 for Earth's gravity. The calculator handles very large (10‚Å¥‚Å∞‚Å∞) and very small (10‚Åª‚Å¥‚Å∞‚Å∞) numbers. For example, calculating energy E=mc¬≤: if m=0.001 kg, then E = 0.001 √ó (3e8)¬≤ = 9e13 joules (90 trillion joules). Great for chemistry mole calculations, astronomy distances, or quantum physics.

sections.title: Pro Tips & Best Practices
content: üí° Use parentheses generously: When in doubt, add extra parentheses to clarify order of operations. The calculator sees 1/2x as (1/2)√óx, not 1/(2x). For complex fractions, use explicit parentheses: (1+2)/(3+4) ensures correct calculation. This prevents 90% of calculation errors. Test your expression with simple numbers first (like all 2s) to verify you've structured it correctly.

üí° Radians for calculus, degrees for geometry: If you're taking derivatives or integrals involving trig functions, ALWAYS use radian mode. If you're finding angles in triangles or working with bearings/navigation, use degree mode. Quick conversion: multiply degrees by œÄ/180 to get radians (90¬∞ = œÄ/2 rad ‚âà 1.57 rad), or multiply radians by 180/œÄ for degrees. Remember: a full circle is 360¬∞ or 2œÄ radians.

üí° Verify with estimation: Before trusting a complex calculation, estimate the answer. If you're calculating 98 √ó 103, estimate ~100 √ó 100 = 10,000 (actual: 10,094). For log(987), since log(1000) = 3, expect slightly less than 3 (actual: 2.994). For sin(30¬∞), remember common values: sin(30¬∞) = 0.5, sin(45¬∞) ‚âà 0.707, sin(60¬∞) ‚âà 0.866. If your answer is way off, check your mode (deg/rad) and parentheses.

üí° Store intermediate results: For multi-step calculations, write down intermediate answers instead of trying to nest everything in one expression. Calculate step-by-step: if solving quadratic formula x = (-b ¬± ‚àö(b¬≤-4ac))/(2a) for a=2, b=5, c=3, first calculate discriminant b¬≤-4ac = 25-24 = 1, then ‚àö1 = 1, then (-5¬±1)/4 giving x = -1 or x = -1.5. This reduces errors and makes it easier to spot mistakes.

üí° Remember special values: Memorize key values to check your work: sin/cos at 0¬∞, 30¬∞, 45¬∞, 60¬∞, 90¬∞ (forms the 0, 0.5, ‚àö2/2, ‚àö3/2, 1 pattern). ln(1) = 0, ln(e) = 1. log(1) = 0, log(10) = 1, log(100) = 2. e ‚âà 2.718, œÄ ‚âà 3.14159. These help you quickly verify if your calculator answer makes sense or if you've made an input error.
